I'm not in a STEM program, but I can tell you that the walk from Victoria College to the other side of campus really isn't really that far - about 10-15 minutes depending on the weather. It[.] actually pretty nice in the fall and the spring, I find it quite peaceful. However, in the winter when Toronto turns into a hellscape, it can be pretty brutal. 

Also, about class locations - I'm a History major going into fourth year and the majority of my classes have been in STEM buildings, so I don't think there[.] a bonafide guarantee that you'll have all your classes on the side of campus closest to New College. 

Regarding scholarships, I was under the impression that Victoria[.] scholarships were mostly humanities-realated, so I'm not sure they'll be much help to you in STEM. 

One last thing, New College is closer to late night, cheap, junk food kind of places - if you're out late and wanna grab something to eat. Victoria is kind of a dead zone for that kind of stuff since it[.] next to Yorkville - which is a really ritzy, high-end neighbourhood. It[.] a lot of designer boutiques and expensive sit-down restaurants. 

Unfortunately, I don't have much personal experience with residence life at either college since I'm at St. Michael[.] and I commute. But, I will say that my one big U of T regret is not considering college choice more carefully when I enrolled - so I wish you the best of luck and I hope I helped a bit! 

EDIT TO ADD: If you do decide to switch over to New College, make sure you look up their transferring policy, because every college is different.
